entry.title: Game: Devil May Cry (HD Collection) (PS3, 2012) (2)
entry.content:
Game: Devil May Cry (HD Collection) (PS3, 2012) (2)20130728
I played today for about two hours. Of that time, about an hour
was spent "grinding" for red orbs so I could get past the boss
fights. Despite doing this, when I got to Mission 6 and had to
fight the Death Scissor I tried over and over again for about
thirty minutes and couldn't beat it. As I mentioned yesterday, I
feel like this game doesn't give you the ability to dodge at all,
so with these one-on-one fights, it feels like there's no strategy
except "Duke-it-out". I really didn't enjoy it.

Total time: 3:04
  • Video Games
  • Devil May Cry (HD Collection)
  • PS3
  • 2012

entry.title: Game: Devil May Cry 2 (HD Collection) (PS3, 2012)
entry.content:
Game: Devil May Cry 2 (HD Collection) (PS3, 2012)20130728
After abandoning Devil May Cry 1, I decided to move on to this
one. I played as Dante (no idea about what's the deal with other
character.) At first, the game feels a lot better. It moves faster
and the mechanics feel tighter. Just being able to clearly see
what enemy you are targeting and see their health bar go down
makes the game feel much nicer. However, the game felt like a
back-and-forth between boring and exploitable enemies and nigh
impossible challenges.

For instance, in Mission 5 there's a sequence with giant Tanks. If
you just slowly circle-strafe them then they can't hurt you at
all, but they soak up a TON of damage from your shotgun. Similarly
with the Chopper a bit later... it can't hit you if you just hang
out under it, but it takes a ton of hits. I finally had enough of
the game when I got to the next section where you have to climb up
a burning building with ridiculously awkward platforming controls.

I can definitely see how this game was the "true form" of what
they realized they wanted to do after making the first game, but
it still wasn't appealing enough for me.

Total time: 1:28
  • Video Games
  • Devil May Cry 2 (HD Collection)
  • PS3
  • 2012

entry.title: Game: Devil May Cry 3: Special Edition (HD Collection) (PS3, 2012)
entry.content:
Game: Devil May Cry 3: Special Edition (HD Collection) (PS3, 2012)20130728
After abandoning the first two games, I moved on to the third. I
played for about an hour and got to Mission 4 and fought the first
big boss---Cerberus. I feel like the game is already a lot
nicer. You can control the camera and it also has the targeting
and health bars (although in a more subtle way) from the second
one. I feel like I'm going to like it a lot better than the other
games. We'll see.

Total time: 0:46
  • Video Games
  • Devil May Cry 3: Special Edition (HD Collection)
  • PS3
  • 2012

entry.title: Game: Devil May Cry (HD Collection) (PS3, 2012)
entry.content:
Game: Devil May Cry (HD Collection) (PS3, 2012)20130727
I played this for about an hour and beat three missions. I've
heard a lot about this from my love of Bayonetta.

In the first three missions, I found it to be a pretty bad
game. It definitely feels like it was originally a Resident Evil
game, with the fixed, stuffy camera angles and the awkward
"adventure game" tropes throughout the castle.

I don't find the combat to be very fluid and I feel like it's
impossible to dodge at all, which means there's almost no
"finesse" to combat. It reminds me of a traditional 2D brawler
where the key is not to dodge, but to evenly spread out your
attacks against a lot of enemies to keep from getting
surrounded. It's definitely a coherent design, but I can't say I
really enjoy it.

The boss battle in the third mission was ridiculous. It felt like
you couldn't hit the thing at all. Eventually, I looked at a FAQ
and it said to dodge, but you can't really move quickly and then
whenever you try to move around the camera angle changes on you so
you turn around. It is infuriating. In the end, I just tried to
spam jump on its back over and over. I'm kind of amazed that I was
able to beat it the time that I did, because it didn't feel any
different on my part from before. I died maybe... 10 times and did
a few different reloads before I won. I felt like just quitting
and saying the game wasn't for me. But since I won, I guess I will
keep going. I'm not excited about it though.

I find the need to hold R1 to use the gun to be very annoying. I
can appreciate its unique "stick shift"-like quality, but it
doesn't feel beautiful or good to me.

Total time: 0:55
  • Video Games
  • Devil May Cry (HD Collection)
  • PS3
  • 2012

entry.title: Game: Nier (PS3, 2010) (4)
entry.content:
Game: Nier (PS3, 2010) (4)20130727
I played today for about three hours and beat it the first time. I
dread the idea of playing three more times just to see more. I
wonder if I'll be able to easily find the differences on
YouTube... the game is definitely fun, but when I think of playing
it again, I just think of all the tedious parts that I will have
to do again and how I *know* that I will win all the
fights... since I've already done it.

--

Later, I started the new file and went through the Kaine dream
sequences that happen right away. It was neat. Then I just watched
the ending videos on YouTube. Since I played with the voices off
the whole time, it was really weird to hear the voices on the
videos.

After watching the videos and reading the NIER Wiki, I was
surprised at some of the details of the story. Some of it I
gathered from my play through, but it was much more clear
(obviously) reading and watching these things.

--

Overall, I thought this game was really cool. The battle system is
so traditional at first glance, but then becomes very unique as
you start getting into the "bullet hell" boss fights. Very cool.

Total time: 15:05
  • Video Games
  • Nier
  • PS3
  • 2010

entry.title: Game: Nier (PS3, 2010) (3)
entry.content:
Game: Nier (PS3, 2010) (3)20130726
Today I went through up to the key in the factory. The reading
comprehension test was crazy. The combat in this game is really
good... the balance between using magic and weapons is fun. I'm
particularly enjoying the spear because you can charge and you're
invulnerable during it. The fight against Kaine was super hard.

entry.title: Game: Nier (PS3, 2010) (2)
entry.content:
Game: Nier (PS3, 2010) (2)20130725
I played today for about three hours. I left the Junk Heap and
went back to The Aerie for the boss fight there. It was pretty
cool, especially the 2D segment. Next, I went to the Facade, which
was really weird, and then The Barren Temple, which had a really
cool boss fight and the puzzle rooms were neat too. The Forest of
Myth was insane... I can't believe it drops you into a text
adventure. Insanity. The Haunted Manor felt like Resident Evil
with the fixed camera angles and gathering shaped keys... so
weird. The boss fight was pretty boring. I feel like I'm not at
the end of the first half because I've gathered the Sealed Verses.

Total time: 7:15
  • Video Games
  • Nier
  • PS3
  • 2010

entry.title: Game: Nier (PS3, 2010)
entry.content:
Game: Nier (PS3, 2010)20130723
I started this game today and played for about four hours. I got
up to the part where you go to the military base. The game is so
weird. It feels like it came from another planet. The introduction
is so abrupt and a lot of the dialogue is incredibly bizarre. The
mechanics are really odd too. Obviously there's the weird fishing
game, which I totally failed at.

But, the most interesting thing to me is when a battle scene pulls
out to an almost 2D perspective and it feels like a bullet hell
shooter where you have to weave your way through geometric
patterns. The boss inside the military base was really cool in
that way.

The style of the game is exceedingly odd too. The main character
is so ugly. The girl Kaine is such a cliche, it feels like
pandering, but then the characters acknowledge that she's
pandering. It's weird. I was really annoyed that I just turned on
the game and within seconds heard almost every cuss word
around. I've been playing with the voice volume off, but haven't
actually heard anything bad.

I get the feeling that there's a huge amount of content I'm
missing by not being meticulous enough with the environments and
quests. I feel like every shop has stuff that appears useless and
is definitely too expensive to be worthwhile.

I am really annoyed at how far all the places I need to go between
are. It would be different if it were a normal RPG where you were
gaining power through the fights, but the progression in this game
seems incredibly slow. Not only are you gain levels very slowly,
but I feel like gaining a new level never matters.

It feels like the game defies you at every step and is just a
stumbling block. It's bizarre.

My final comment for the day... it is totally absurd that there
are two versions of this game in Japan and that the character
design is a Western cliche. I think the Japanese one looks a lot
better.

Total time: 3:56
  • Video Games
  • Nier
  • PS3
  • 2010

entry.title: Game: Shin Megami Tensei: Persona 4 Golden (Vita, 2012) (27)
entry.content:
Game: Shin Megami Tensei: Persona 4 Golden (Vita, 2012) (27)20130723
I played for about an hour this morning. I first recharged my SP
by fighting basic monsters in the Castle. Then, I fought the final
boss. Debilitate was great and Trumpeter is immune to most
attacks, so it was awesome.

The true ending is neat... especially all the new character
outfits, especially Naoto's since she never wore female clothes
before.

It's kind of amazing that it is exactly three months since I
started the game. I think that's too long to play the same game
though. I definitely liked it a lot, but I was a bit worn out by
the end.

I still need to watch the TV listings, but I won't count that as
play time.... they weren't that interesting.

Total time: 75:33
  • Video Games
  • Shin Megami Tensei: Persona 4 Golden
  • Vita
  • 2012

entry.title: Game: Shin Megami Tensei: Persona 4 Golden (Vita, 2012) (26)
entry.content:
Game: Shin Megami Tensei: Persona 4 Golden (Vita, 2012) (26)20130722
I grinded today for thirty minutes. I'm not sure how long I should
go before going back to the ground floor, selling my stuff, and
re-equipping for another attempt at the final fight. I feel like
Rise's skills are to the point where I can fight indefinitely,
especially I just go over one of the easy dungeons to recharge.

--

Later in the day I did more grinding for about three hours. I
fought the final boss again but died in the second form. So, I did
more grinding and fused Trumpeter so that I can use Debilitate
against the final boss. I'll try again tomorrow... and hopefully
win.

Total time: 74:30

  • Vita

entry.title: Movie: Star Trek XI: Star Trek (2009)
entry.content:
Movie: Star Trek XI: Star Trek (2009)20130721
The beginning of this movie makes me cry every time. I've seen it
three times and it always does it.

It's cool that there are lots of little ideas and quotes that come
from the other movies.

Scenes like when Scotty is stuck in the tubes are fun and show off
the ship and future technology, but they are ultimately
pointless. It's strange that they're there at all.

This is an awesome movie.
  • Movies
  • 2009

entry.content:

This was really cool. I can't believe he climbed up the

entry.title: Movie: Star Trek X: Nemesis, starring Patrick Stewart (2002)
entry.content:
Movie: Star Trek X: Nemesis, starring Patrick Stewart (2002)20130721
I like all the jokes about Romulan Ale across the whole series.

Like the previous movie about the Borg, I feel like this movie
assumes you know a lot about the Romulans, which I'm ignorant
about.

I also didn't realize that Deanna wasn't Human.

It's amazing how often these movies are about duplicated, cloned,
and resurrected people.

The chase scene was very un-Star-Trek.

His name is "B-4". Hah.

The outfits of these guys are ridiculous.

Given how huge the ships look from space, I find it implausible
that people ever accidentally run into each other while walking
around. Furthermore, when they have big shoot outs in huge
hallways, you just wonder... why did they make that huge corridor
in the first place? It just seems like a big waste of resources.

The whole fast aging clone thing is clearly taken from Metal
Gear. :)

I'm continually amazed that Star Trek captains give their orders by
voice when things are happening so quickly. It seems like more
autonomous work would be more efficient.

All of the action sequences in this movie are lame.

It seems like the try to use self-destruct of the Enterprise in
*every* movie. It's crazy. Similarly, every movie has an epic fight
while a countdown is going off.

While there were a few neat moments, this movie definitely was not
one of the best ones.
  • Movies
  • 2002

entry.title: Movie: Star Trek IX: Insurrection, starring Patrick Stewart (1998)
entry.content:
Movie: Star Trek IX: Insurrection, starring Patrick Stewart (1998)20130721
The culture being monitored at the beginning was very
fascinating. I thought it was bizarre that they said there were
just 600 people on the planet though. It seems like a waste of
planet. Prior to Picard's discussion with their leader, I thought
it was impossible that such a small population could exist with the
amount of culture they seemed to have. Afterwards, it seems
implausible that they would take such a small group to leave there.

I love what Riker says about Whorf's pimple: "Klingons never do
anything small, huh?"

This was a really cool movie, definitely one of the best.
  • Movies
  • 1998

entry.title: Movie: Warm Bodies, starring Nicholas Hoult (2013)
entry.content:
Movie: Warm Bodies, starring Nicholas Hoult (2013)20130720
This was an amazing movie. When I first heard about the plot, I
assumed it would be stupid and they couldn't possibly earn its
premise. Yet, they did an amazing job right from the get-go. I
thought the allusions to Romeo & Juliet were brilliant, as well as
subtle. It's exciting to think about a zombie movie from the
perspective of the zombies :)

I loved the part about the digital zombies in the past.
  • Movies
  • 2013

entry.title: Movie: Star Trek VIII: First Contact, starring Patrick Stewart (1996)
entry.content:
Movie: Star Trek VIII: First Contact, starring Patrick Stewart (1996)20130719
This movie has a really bizarre set up. I wish there was a better
introduction to the Borg.

It was very interesting to see the preamble to the "First Contact"
event in Star Trek history. I really like the way the guy isn't
interested in being a hero. It's a very intriguing idea to think
about knowing about how you will be remember and how you would
react to that knowledge.

The zero-G fight was really stressful if you really thought about
what was going on, but it was shot in such a passive style that it
seemed like it didn't matter at all.

It's so weird that Borg hardly react to the crew at all. I guess
they aren't supposed to be like "cells" of a larger creature, but
rather things that are semi-autonomous but get occasional commands.

I'm surprised when the Enterprise crew plan to blow up the ship,
they don't discuss how they will get back to the future. Although
they did talk about how the people still on Earth should stay there
and "not affect" history. But then the people on the Enterprise
looked like they were going to Earth... it seems like they *have*
to recover the Enterprise and then go home safely.
  • Movies
  • 1996

entry.title: Movie: Star Trek VII: Generations, starring Patrick Stewart (1994)
entry.content:
Movie: Star Trek VII: Generations, starring Patrick Stewart (1994)20130719
I wrote down a lot about this movie as I was watching it:

This was a very confusing movie in the beginning, because I know
nothing about the new crew of the Enterprise and I felt that there
were a lot more references to their past, as opposed to the earlier
movies which seemed more modular vis-a-vis the TV series.

In particular, I'm confused about why there are no Vulcans,
although clearly Data is supposed to be like Spock.

The movie felt very similar to V in the middle, because we have a
guy, crazed, trying to get to a place of religious significance.

I don't get how the Borg are mentioned in this as doing something
in the distant past, when Captain Kirk should have been active. Is
there an original episode with the Borg too? I thought that was a
Picard thing.

Why are there tons of kids and civilians on the ship? During the
"separation scene", you see lots of them.

After watching seven movies, it seems so unbelievable that the
ships are so fragile and they are constantly breaking in many ways
and there are always "turbulence"-like problems where they are
being rocked back and forth. It seems so weird given the otherwise
technological superiority.

In this movie, it was crazy when the ship crashed... how could they
possibility get out of the situation and rebuilt the ship on a
primitive world? Although I guess it didn't look like that much
damage was done... until the whole planet was destroyed at
least. This has to be an "alternate" reality? I guess I failed to
remember that they could contact other people to help them.

It was intense to see Kirk die. I guess he was wrong though... he
didn't die alone.
  • Movies
  • 1994

entry.title: Movie: Star Trek VI: The Undiscovered Country, starring William Shatner (1991)
entry.content:
Movie: Star Trek VI: The Undiscovered Country, starring William Shatner (1991)20130718
This was a quite different movie than the others. For instance, it
took a long time for a principal enemy to appear. I thought the
details were very neat and the idea of a murder mystery as the
subject was fun. I don't feel like there were as many memorable
moments, though.
  • Movies

entry.title: Movie: Star Trek V: The Final Frontier, starring William Shatner (1989)
entry.content:
Movie: Star Trek V: The Final Frontier, starring William Shatner (1989)20130718
The beginning of this movie is a very good homage to the last one
as it revolves around how odd it is to have Spock in the 'real'
world.

I had heard that this movie was about a journey to meet God, which
of course it was, but I was very disappointed that it wasn't really
God and then they gave no explanation whatever for what was going
on with him.
  • Movies
  • 1989
